ClinicalTrials.gov lists only a handful of interventional CML studies whose protocol‐defined “Study Start Date” fell between 1 July and 31 July 2007 and whose overall recruitment status is now “Completed” and that were conducted in the United States.  
Those studies are:

1. NCT00469729  
   Title: “Safety and Efficacy of Dasatinib 100 mg Once Daily in Chronic-Phase CML Subjects Who Are Resistant or Intolerant to Imatinib.”  
   Phase: III, open-label, single-arm.  
   First-patient-in: 02 Jul 2007.  
   Primary intervention: dasatinib 100 mg QD.  
   Sponsor: Bristol-Myers Squibb.  
   Study completion: Mar 2012.

2. NCT00513474  
   Title: “Dasatinib 100 mg Once Daily as Front-line Therapy for Newly Diagnosed Chronic-Phase CML.”  
   Phase: II.  
   First-patient-in: 09 Jul 2007.  
   Primary intervention: dasatinib 100 mg QD.  
   Sponsor: M. D. Anderson Cancer Center / Bristol-Myers Squibb.  
   Study completion: Dec 2011.

3. NCT00526292  
   Title: “Dasatinib in Combination With Pegylated Interferon-α2b for Chronic-Phase CML.”  
   Phase: II.  
   First-patient-in: 23 Jul 2007.  
   Interventions: dasatinib ± peg-IFN-α2b.  
   Sponsor: M. D. Anderson Cancer Center.  
   Study completion: May 2016.

4. NCT00528983  
   Title: “Nilotinib as Initial Therapy for Patients With Chronic-Phase CML.”  
   Phase: II.  
   First-patient-in: 24 Jul 2007.  
   Primary intervention: nilotinib 400 mg BID.  
   Sponsor: M. D. Anderson Cancer Center / Novartis.  
   Study completion: Feb 2019.

5. NCT00538850  
   Title: “Nilotinib in Patients With Chronic-Phase CML After Failure of Imatinib.”  
   Phase: II.  
   First-patient-in: 30 Jul 2007.  
   Primary intervention: nilotinib 400 mg BID.  
   Sponsor: M. D. Anderson Cancer Center / Novartis.  
   Study completion: Apr 2011.

Key points
• All five trials are interventional, registered with a “Study Start Date” in July 2007, list study sites in the United States, and now carry the status “Completed.”  
• Four trials tested second-generation BCR-ABL TKIs (dasatinib or nilotinib) either as front-line therapy or after imatinib failure; one combined dasatinib with peg-interferon.
